title: How would I come up with good names for a fictional country? - The Writer’s Nook - Quora

response.answer_text: If you are creating a “country” in a world far different than the Earth… Name it whatever you want with a combination of pleasing mouth sounds. Or use a blending of languages that infer a general ecological niche (Greensward, Mountaindale, Fenlake, Seastone, etc.) If you name your country Xzybafid, you better have a reason that makes enough sense that your readers won't come to a screeching halt saying…”Xzybafid? WTF?” If you haven't established (or do not later divulge) that “Xzy” (pronounced “'Zy”) means “Sky” and “b” means “of” and “afid” means “old dwelling place”, then the whole venture is a useless conceit. Better to just say “Lake Town” or “Hobbiton”…

Find little-known countries or cities in the “theme” of the country you want to create a name for, then figure out what makes those names tick and make an amalgamation of those names. For example, “Wakanda” sounds like a real African country. You might take something like Estonia and Latvia (they border each other) and make “Latonia” or “Estovia” (I think Wachovia was used in Age of Ultron, or something close to that name). Actually, “Estovia” sounds kind of cool, and you’re welcome to use it. Tom Hanks heralded from “Krakozhia” in The Terminal and that sounds pretty legit. From Ambrosia to Zuy
